sections.name: Genre
sections.blurb: These awards are given to the anime from each genre that displayed all-around excellence compared to the competition. Each show is assigned to one of seven genre categories, and a winner is chosen within each category.

nominees.writeup: While Keijo probably won't be remembered as a critically acclaimed work for posteriority, its copious amounts of butt puns, over-the-top battles, and revolutionary fanservice makes it a very entertaining watch that does actually have a healthy dose of fantasstic action. It's really something else when two girls in swimsuits smasshing against each other looks like a stand battle out of JoJo.
nominees.staff:
Xebec

Directed by Hideya Takahashi

nominees.writeup: We felt that Haikyuu!! succeeded the most as an action series in 2016 because it was able to elicit the strongest reactions from us. No other nominee in this category got us more hyped or excited while watching the action unfold. Haikyuu is able to create a strong connection between its sports setting and the audience by being exemplary in virtually every category that is important for the genre. This includes superb animation, skilled direction, complete clarity of action, and excellent character development right on the court. Both of the consistently high-quality seasons that aired in 2016 are worthy of the top spot.
nominees.staff:
Production I.G

Directed by Susumu Mitsunaka

nominees.writeup: A real treat for Shonen fans. Boku no Hero Academia builds a fantastic base for the rest of the series with its very own superhero origin origin story. Although the first season was slow paced as an adaptation, be on the lookout for season 2. Great animation from Bones and a cast of likable heroes make this anime a comfortable pick as one of the best action series of 2016.
nominees.staff:
BONES

Directed by Kenji Nagasaki

nominees.altname: JoJo Part IV: Diamond is Unbreakable
nominees.writeup: Part 4 of JoJo, as with the previous parts, is an excellent series that is a totally unique blend of genres and concepts. One of the things it excels in especially is action, as shown in the crazy stand battles, full of creativity and spectacle. However, when it comes to action alone, we felt that Mob Psycho 100 and Haikyuu surpass JoJo most notably through their superior production values among other aspects.
nominees.staff:
David Production

Directed by Naokatsu Tsuda

nominees.writeup: Mob Psycho 100 really floored us with its incredible fight scenes, and we unanimously agree that it has the best animation out of all the nominees. However, when it came to generating hype and having clarity of action, something we feel is very important, Haikyuu came out on top. Overall though, Mob Psycho 100 succeeds at everything it set out to do, including having top-notch action sequences.
nominees.staff:
BONES

Directed by Yuzuru Tachikawa

nominees.writeup: Concrete Revolutio has a unique artstyle, amazing action animation, and a smorgasbord of superheroes, kaiju, magical girls, aliens, robots and yokai, the result is a fantasy melting pot unlike any other in anime. ConRevo's deep thematic investigation on justice, freedom, peaceful, maybe marred by its convoluted and overambitious narrative, but it's still a great pick as our fourth nominee.
nominees.staff:
BONES

Directed by Seiji Mizushima

nominees.writeup: Alderamin on the Sky follows Ikta and his friends in their historical fantasy-esque world. Alderamin delves into the grittier side of war and successfully does so without being too serious and overbearing. Ikta and Yatori are the standout characters, and their platonic relationship is beautifully portrayed and rarely seen in anime. The show doesn't bring anything revolutionary to the table, but is still an entertaining watch, and well placed as fifth on the list.
nominees.staff:
MADHOUSE

Directed by Tetsuo Ichimura

nominees.writeup: Drifters is an absurdity, filled with a hodgepodge of generic fantasy races and historical characters, a smattering of random themes, and gratuitous amounts of violence and bloodshed. The show may suffer from massive tonal whiplashes and overdesigned characters, but if the idea of Oda Nobunaga commanding a firing line of topless men appeals to you, it is worth checking out, yet still lands at sixth place in our list.
nominees.staff:
Hoods Entertainment


Directed by Kenichi Suzuki

nominees.writeup: Grimgar is a realistic take on the isekai subgenre, which revels in both the mundane and the adventurous, it's take on adaptation to a new world, the bonds of friendship and grief, make it a satisfyingly deep and effective work. Its also a thrill to see the cast improve themselves from bumbling fools to competent adventures though grinding and planning. Mary's arc in particular is a testament to its nuanced writing. Combine all this with its gorgeous watercolor aesthetic and you have a deserving number three.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures


Directed by Ryousuke Nakamura

nominees.writeup: Flip Flappers for the majority of its run consisted of episodic adventures with vibrant animation and dynamic fight sequences, that could be wondrous, horrific, tense, or exciting depending on the episode's theme. But as the layers of symbols and references kept building, and the main plot revealed itself in a struggle for identity and self against the umwelt, diving down Flip Flappers' twisted bildungsroman became a veritable adventure onto itself. A work of art unlike any other, Flip Flappers more than deserves to be the best adventure/fantasy of the year.
nominees.staff:
Studio 3Hz

Directed by Kiyotaka Oshiyama

nominees.writeup: Re:Zero is a great example of genre subversion, demonstrating the "darker side" of the isekai genre. It has excellent voice acting, stunning animation, multidimensional characters, and a time loop mechanic that is well used. Its world is fairly generic though, and it doesn't get into an adventure until its last arc, and a lot of its interesting ideas are dropped for a conclusive but disappointing finale. Despite that it struck a deep enough emotional chord with the jury, that we decided it deserves the second place spot.
nominees.staff:
White Fox


Directed by Masaharu Watanabe

nominees.writeup: Space Patrol Luluco is Trigger through and through, it is as off-beat, zany, and over-the-top as anything else by Trigger. It's humor is almost entirely slapstick or meta referential, which is its greatest strength and its biggest weakness as you need to like Trigger and its related Gainax works to enjoy this show. Still as a love letter to all things Trigger, the show is good enough to place as the fourth nominee
nominees.staff:
Trigger

Directed by Hiroyuki Imaishi

nominees.writeup: Working is a very charming and rather funny SoL rom-com with a nice romantic conclusion and some really good comedic moments. It has a pretty good main cast, but is let down by some weak characters and the excessive repetition of a couple of jokes. Despite this, it is still a fun and incredibly easy to watch show that's well placed as our fifth nominee.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures

Directed by Yumi Kamakura

nominees.writeup:
30 young men and women who came together on a shady bus tour. The tour's destination: an illusive, possibly nonexistent village called Nanakimura. In Nanakimura, one can lead a utopian existence, free of the world's obstacles … or so it was rumored, like an urban legend.

"In despair over the real world ... wanting to escape the tedious daily life … wanting to restart your life from scratch …"

The bus headed deep into the mountains, carrying 30 people each harboring their own expectations and wounds in their hearts…

And so, the place these 30 arrived at, was an uninhabited village with the lingering faint scents of life, even though it was falling apart.

What is the truth of Nanakimura facing the 30? You can't miss even one episode!
nominees.staff:
diomedéa

Directed by Tsutomu Mizushima

nominees.writeup: Sakamoto desu ga? had a great premise which was marred by poor execution. There are a quite few funny gags here but they are bogged down by the shows formulaic and repetitive structure. The show could have been greatly improved by a shorter runtime and a better ensemble, but it is still worth checking out for Sakamoto's coolness, and fits well as the sixth nominee.
nominees.staff:
Studio DEEN

Directed by Shinji Takamatsu

nominees.writeup: Tanaka-kun is Always Listless is a chill comedy, which is equal parts hilarious and comfy. The show has incredible confidence in every aspect of its execution including its smart direction, soothing artstyle, calming soundtrack, impeccable comic timing, and one of the best ensembles this year. There were some complaints about its large amount of slice of life moments, which drops the show down to  second place.
nominees.staff:
SILVER LINK.

Directed by Shinya Kawatsura

nominees.writeup: Saiki Kusuo no Psi-nan is the funniest show this year, it features a deadpan psychic trying to live a quiet, peaceful life who has to deal with a truly massive and varied cast of characters who won't let him have his peace, this leads to a ton of top notch gags and some misses, but the show is smart enough to move past what doesn't work, and always experiments with new gags, keeping its humor always fresh and entertaining. Confidently making it the jury's best comedy of the year.
nominees.staff:
J.C. Staff

Directed by Hiroaki Sakurai

nominees.writeup: KonoSuba is a refreshing take on the Isekai subgenre, with its parodic, almost mean spirited humor, and interesting cast of characters particularly Kazuma, Aqua and Megumin. Production wise, it may have Deen's QUALITY animation but aside from that it features some fantastic VA performances, an ingenious soundtrack, and top notch comic timing. The show's overuse of certain gags, and a weaker side cast slightly bring it down to a solid third place nominee.
nominees.staff:
Studio DEEN

Directed by Takaomi Kanasaki

hms.name: Kono Bijutsubu ni wa Mondai ga Aru!

nominees.writeup: Planetarian is a short but powerful drama that seeks to explore subjects as rich as determinism vs free will, the purpose of duty in identity, and the allure of cute anime robot girls. The show focuses on Yumemi, a robotic interface with a decidedly human personality, and the Junker, a man seeking purpose in a world without any. The two are characterized with depth, resulting in the trademark hackneyed Key finale actually feeling heartfelt and genuine, and making it a worthy candidate for third place.
nominees.staff:
David Production

Directed by Naokatsu Tsuda

nominees.writeup: Fune wo Amu is a very down-to-earth slice of life that features a humane, realistic, and genuine approach towards drama. Its characters are well-written, and the show addresses complicated everyday situations in the workplace beautifully, a subject that is rarely touched upon in anime. While the jury agrees that Fune wo Amu is a great series, it doesn't have a lot of dramatic heft due to trivial and easily resolved conflicts, which necessitates its fourth place.
nominees.staff:
ZEXCS

Directed by Toshimasa Kuroyanagi

nominees.writeup: Kiznaiver has an excellent visual aesthetic, superb character animation, and an interesting setting. As the fun cast of characters is forced to interact by the Kizuna system's idiosyncrasies, the show delves into its characters' inner working, as highlighted by Honoka's haunting backstory. However, as the story drifts away from character backstories and begins focusing on its overwrought and hokey love polygon, the show becomes bogged down in melodrama. Overall, a good show, but in terms of well-developed drama, it was lacking in comparison to the other nominees.
nominees.staff:
Trigger

Directed by Hiroshi Kobayashi

nominees.writeup: Hibike! Euphonium 2's atmospheric and immersive production sets the stage for what becomes a remarkably heartfelt and emphatic drama, as the show explores conflicts that arise from the rekindling of friendships and oppressive parenting cultures. Kumiko's return to the spotlight is shared with the deceitfully strong-willed Asuka, who's introspection slowly breaks apart her seemingly untroubled facade. While the first of the two arcs within the show may feel uneven at times, the relatable characters make it easy to sympathize with, and the show's impactful and satisfying conclusion leaves a memorable impression that easily awards itself second place.
nominees.staff:
Kyoto Animation

Directed by Tatsuya Ishihara

nominees.writeup: Shouwa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu is a dramatic masterpiece, and the secret to its success lies in the care and precision of its narrative. There are few huge climaxes, few tearful showdowns, few major fights; Rakugo simply carries the audience through the life and struggles of two young men, as disparate in character as they are kindred in spirit. The voice actors do an admirable job of making you feel their struggles: evocatively painting their triumphs, their mistakes, and all the unstated injustices the plot has to unveil. Rakugo's maturity, depth, and passion towards its story makes it our best drama of the year.
nominees.staff:
Studio DEEN

Directed by Shinichi Omata

nominees.writeup: Honobono Log is a short series of romantic vignettes clocking in at 2 minutes per episode. Even with this short runtime, it manages to tackle situations of love that feel authentic and can elicit many different emotions. It ranges from heartwarming to heartbreaking and is able to make you care about these characters, just before you leave them for good. Each episode functions like a short poem, leaving the viewer to fill in the details and imagine the rest of the story. But, what is here is great. It's filled with the small, but meaningful interactions between established adult couples that we'd love to see more of in romance shows going forward.
nominees.staff:
Fanworks

Directed by Kumi Matsui

nominees.writeup: Momokuri is almost oppressively cute, but over the course of the show, the characters discover they need to learn to accept the unique quirks of each other's personalities in order to make their relationship work. It starts off right away with a confession and relationship, rather than pussyfooting around with one character summoning the courage to confess for 8 episodes. Even though both the main characters are ultra-shy and inexperienced, they still push themselves to progress their relationship, even if it's in tiny ways. Yuki's incessant stalking of Momo comes off as cute and funny rather than creepy and off-putting. Our main complaint is that the series meanders a bit too much in the middle and major progression between the main characters stalls until the final episodes.
nominees.staff:
Satelight

Directed by Yoshimasa Hiraike

nominees.writeup: Orange is a show that tries to demonstrate how love and friendship can literally save a person's life. However, a romance can live and die by the strength of its main pairing. Naho and Kakeru leave a lot to be desired. Naho is frustratingly lacking in agency and emotional intelligence, and doesn't have any other interesting facets or backstory to make up for it. Kakeru is, understandably, not focused on romance because he has other demons to deal with first. When the romance between a side pairing is infinitely more fun to watch, your main pairing has a lot of work to do. We would love to reach out our hand to Orange, but we're not sure the show would understand what we meant by that gesture. Not recommended.
nominees.staff:
Telecom Animation Film

Directed by Hiroshi Hamasaki

nominees.writeup: The show takes place in Ogikubo, which is the name of the specially designated area in space in the Milky Way where Earthlings and aliens can live together. Luluco is a female middle school student who lives with her father, and no matter where she is, Luluco is a common, "super normal" girl. As she is living her normal life, one day the mysterious transfer student ΑΩ Nova abruptly appears before her. That meeting will change Luluco's fate.
nominees.staff:
Trigger

Directed by Hiroyuki Imaishi

nominees.writeup: Yuri on Ice provided some of the most impactful romantic moments of the year. The passion and electricity between Yuri and Viktor was palpable and kept us all on the edge of our seats from episode to episode. Whether they were running to each other in the airport, or swiftly skating to rinkside for a hug, the almost desperate desire to be close to one another made Yuri and Viktor's romance very intriguing to follow. Unfortunately, it seemed that the show was always holding something back, for all the scenes it did give us. From the "kiss" scene to the "engagement" ring they almost playfully avoid making anything explicit to the extent that someone could make an argument that their relationship isn't one of romantic love, but rather based only on admiration and friendship. It is difficult to pinpoint if Yuri even truly understands the difference between romantic love and admiration or gratitude. The show further avoids romantic interactions by focusing heavily on skating in its second half, which left a ton of loose threads to be resolved in a final episode, which still never made clear what feelings Yuri had for Viktor as a lover, as a coach, as a competitor, or as a friend. We hope the show wholeheartedly embraces its subtext in future seasons.
nominees.staff:
MAPPA

Directed by Sayo Yamamoto

nominees.writeup: This show is a very traditional fairytale romance. Luckily it breaks with shoujo tradition because the protagonist, Shirayuki, is a godsend for shoujo female leads, easily one of the best we've seen. She is a strong, capable, and independent woman who has the determination and kind charisma to succeed without the help of the princely suitors in her life. Throughout the second season Prince Zen and Shirayuki are separated for long periods of time, but Shirayuki takes these opportunities to earn the respect of everyone around her and change her kingdom for the better. All the while, Zen and Shirayuki's love for each other only grows deeper, even from a great distance, as they overcome all obstacles to return to each others' side. When the two finally do reunite, they are on more equal footing, and the romance between them is justified in both the eyes of the kingdom and the viewer. Even while they are apart, the romantic side stories between other cast members will do plenty to keep romance fans grinning from ear to ear.
nominees.staff:
BONES

Directed Masahiro Ando

nominees.writeup: ReLIFE gives its main character the chance to go back to high school with all of the knowledge and wisdom he has acquired as a 27-year-old.  The chemistry between the main cast of characters was generally very good, leading to a consistent supply of hilarious and endearing moments. Watching Arata and An ship together their younger friends, Rena and Oga, urging them to push through their teenage angst and accept that they just needed to hook up already, was really enjoyable. Sadly this show struggles in a classic romance sense, because it is an incomplete adaptation. One could potentially choose to view the show as a Romeo & Juliet-style tragic romance where the two mains grow fonder of each other, but whose relationship is star-crossed and seems like it will never resolve itself. In any case, the main pairing sees little progression in this first season, so we are left to wonder at what might be.
nominees.staff:
TMS Entertainment

Directed by Tomo Kosaka

nominees.writeup: Ping Pong Girls is a blast. It has spectacular animation, a pulsating soundtrack, a fun cast of characters that undergo deep characterization, as they play and learn ping pong and understand their own desires and reasons for competing, playing and falling in love with the game of ping pong. The show realizes its setting well, and focuses on the characters not only as ping pong players but as friends and teammates who hang out and have fun together, leading to some very cute slice of life moments, but there was some debate regarding the extent of its validity as a SoL, placing the show as our number five pick.
nominees.staff:
Kinema Citrus

Directed by Yasuhiro Irie

nominees.altname: This Art Club has a Problem!
nominees.writeup: With one of the better ensembles of the year enters Konobi. While the characters aren't necessarily complex they were indeed funny with their hilarious interactions being the backbone of this show. The variety of gags kept the show fresh and avoided the cardinal sin of repeating the same joke too many times. Konobi is a show that knew exactly what it wanted to accomplish and passed with flying colours, unfortunately this meant Konobi did not have a very high ceiling which results in it taking sixth place out of the nominees.
nominees.staff:
feel.

Directed by Kei Oikawa

nominees.writeup: Amanchu was overall a beautiful and relaxing watch. It has gorgeous scenery, peaceful music, a deeply nostalgic atmosphere, which makes it perfect choice for winding down. Unfortunately, it's great atmosphere, is marred by annoying character sounds and an overuse of reaction faces. Still its look on daily societal anxieties is deeply affecting and definitely worth placing as our second best slice of life this year.
nominees.staff:
J.C. Staff

Directed by Kenichi Kasai

nominees.writeup: Another season of Natsume Yuujinchou for better or for worse. This show was quite divisive among the judges with its supporters enjoying the show's atmosphere, heartwarming stories, and focus on Natsume's friends and family in the latest season. While its detractors found the show to be quite boring with very few of the episodes hitting their mark. Whether or not Natsume Yuujinchou has overstayed it's welcome is up for debate, what is not up for debate however is its position in these awards. Natsume will be taking home the title of fourth best slice of life of the year.
nominees.staff:
Studio Shuka

Directed by Takahiro Omori, Kotomi Deai

nominees.writeup: Having lost his wife, math teacher Kouhei Inuzuka is doing his best to raise his young daughter Tsumugi as a single father. He's pretty bad at cooking and doesn't have a huge appetite to begin with, but chance brings his little family and one of his students, Kotori Iida, together for homemade adventures. With those three cooks in the kitchen, it's no wonder this dinner table drama is so delicious.
nominees.staff:
TMS Entertainment

Directed by Tarou Iwasaki

nominees.writeup: New Game is a well-executed CGDCT show which takes place in a game developing company, a fresh and interesting setting which allows it to introduce new themes of the working conditions in Japan, being the new recruit in an established team, and insights into the job of a game designer, alas this is a typical moe show which deals with these themes very light-heartedly, but having a fairly fun cast of characters and some sweet yuri undertones, places it as the third best slice of life of the year.
nominees.staff:
Doga Kobo

Directed by Yoshiyuki Fujiwara

nominees.writeup: Flying Witch was by far the comfiest anime of the year. Its laidback but charming cast, beautiful setting, standout soundtrack, and subdued but wondrous displays of magic, made the show a delight to watch. Akane's witch wisdom and Chinatsu's childlike wonder, in particular, were highlights in giving the show momentum. Although it had its dissenters, for having a mostly bland cast and not using its premise well, Flying Witch ended up comfortably winning the best slice of life of the year award.
nominees.staff:
J.C. Staff

Directed by Katsushi Sakurabi

nominees.writeup: Ajin's first season was some of the best anime we received this year. The CG surprisingly worked quite well for the show, especially during its action scenes. Satou as a villain was excellent, and the way he swapped Mentor and Badass Immortal Soldier whenever necessary did a great job of helping the show hit its next story beat. The narrative unfortunately fell apart during the second season, escalating too far too fast and leaving too many plotholes and characters by the wayside in the process. However, when it was good, Ajin was utterly unstoppable and that level of early quality earned it our #1 pick.
nominees.staff:
POLYGON PICTURES

Directed by Hiroyuki Seshita, Hiroaki Ando

nominees.writeup: MGRP had promise, and with some minor tweaks or a longer runtime, it could have been a strong contender. There wasn't anything wrong with the character designs, the scenario, or even the message the story was trying to get across. The idea of taking various virtues of magical girls and exaggerating them into vices is a very clever one, and a lot of good characters came out of it. But with 16 characters, and a format that ensured only one could survive, the show turned into a mess, quickly bouncing from backstory to murder to backstory again without pause. There might be enjoyment to be had in this show somewhere, and maybe the source material had the length required to make it into something worth consuming, but the anime is a mess through and through, and we cannot in good faith recommend anyone watch it.
nominees.staff:
Lerche

Directed by Hiroyuki Hashimoto

nominees.writeup: Makoto Naegi, the Ultimate Hope who defeated the Ultimate Despair, Junko Enoshima, is under suspicion of treason against the Future Foundation for harboring the Remnants of Despair who carried on her will. As top members of the Future Foundation, including Makoto's former classmates Kyoko Kirigiri, Aoi Asahina, and Yasuhiro Hagakure, are brought together to decide on Makoto's punishment, they are all imprisoned by Monokuma, who forces everyone to participate in a final killing game. They must try to find the traitor among them who will kill them in their sleep, while also trying to avoid being mortally poisoned by personalised forbidden actions. Thrust into a game where no one can trust each other, Makoto's ideals of hope are pushed to their very limits.
nominees.staff:
Lerche

Directed by Seiji Kishi, Daiki Fukuoka

nominees.writeup:
The Good Side - The pacing of Occultic;Nine was an asset when it came to telling a story of interwoven characters. A first episode at breakneck speed, that barely slowed down after, allowed every major character to be introduced in just 24 minutes. The many plot twists were properly foreshadowed, so each one hit like a truck, instantly creating interest to watch more. Subtle directing tricks help create a tense atmosphere that the show expertly maintains. These elements come together to create a gripping story of the supernatural gone wrong, a treat for many a thriller fan who gives Occultic;Nine a watch.

The Bad Side - On a scene by scene basis, Occultic; Nine gleamed with polish. Unfortunately, when viewed as a whole, the entire structure of the show comes tumbling down. Characters get entire episodes of backstory, only to become completely irrelevant and never mentioned again. The cast was too large for the number of episodes the show received, leading a lot of roles being superfluous. The plot, in an attempt to keep you guessing as to its eventual destination, ends up going nowhere. Ultimately, none of the characters felt relatable and the horrid pacing of the show just killed any sense of dramatic tension before it could be properly cashed in.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures

Directed by Kyouhei Ishiguro

nominees.writeup: Durarara is at its strongest when its large cast of characters, each with their own motives and plans, collided in one big moshpit of coincidence and conflict. It aims a little too high unfortunately, having just too many characters to consistently keep track of, and one too many coincidences to keep the suspension of disbelief going. What's worse, the show introduces new characters early in the season, only to have them absent from most of the major events due to their lack of involvement. The unnecessary extra Saikas, combined with the forced reset to status quo at the end, leaves the show thing feeling empty without stakes. It had its thrills, and the plot managed to get its message across in an interesting way, but Durarara is just held back by too many flaws to take it higher on this list.
nominees.staff:
Studio Shuka

Directed by Takahiro Omori

nominees.writeup: It's obvious from the get go that the creators of 91 Days were not going for a fresh new take on the mafia genre. 91 Days is a classic revenge story, with all the tropes you'd expect from Prohibition-Era Chicago, and tons of references to the various genre works that have come before it. The show did a great job living up to illustrious titles like Godfather, Scarface, and Goodfellas. The creators used every trick from those classic mafia thrillers, and they use them well. Inventive cinematography combined with a rich genre history of symbolism make for a compelling watch. However, the lack of creativity leads to a plot you can see coming from a mile off, which is why it's only able to claim second place. But even then, it's worth giving recognition to a rock solid execution of a simple concept.
nominees.staff:
Studio Shuka

Directed by Hiro Kaburagi

nominees.writeup: The main problem with Erased was the use of its mystery elements. Mysteries that aren't solvable by the viewer aren't in themselves sins, they can be used to great effect to generate tension and atmosphere. A good thriller can draw the viewer in, taunting them with answers they can't have unless they watch just one more episode and Erased hit that beat very often its first half. Unfortunately after that point, the show has difficulty hitting its stride and really tying all the loose ends together well. Only one unanswered question at that point remains and the show takes far too long to answer that, which robs the viewers of any kind of tension and relief. A deeply unsatisfying ending only cemented this show's place.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures

Directed by Tomohiko Itou

sections.name: Character
sections.blurb: These awards are given to the characters with exceptional writing among both dramatic and comedic roles, as well as memorable antagonists and casts.

nominees.writeup: Josuke is an interesting departure from previous JoJo protagonists. Nobody expects him to save the world from any supernatural monsters, so he just gets to be a goofy kid. Sure, he gets mixed up with a serial killer along the way, but he takes a backseat in that. While Jotaro and Rohan are hunting a murderer, Josuke is going to school and coming up with clever money making schemes. The issue is, he's not the best character in his own show; he's arguably not even the most important character in his own show. One could make a strong case that the only reason Josuke is even considered the main character is that Koichi has a little less screen time and his name isn't in the title. Josuke also doesn't really have a character arc or any character development to speak of. Unlike Koichi or Rohan, he's a static character who acts exactly the same at the beginning of the Part as at the end. He's excellent in all his interactions with the characters and the unique relationships he forms with each of them, but falls a bit short as an individual.

Chitose Karasuma's blend of endearing, cynical and egotistical should be, on paper, an awfully despicable character with a bloated sense of importance - clearly nothing to be liked. But because in real life, nobody is perfectly reflective of their idealized versions of themselves, the brutal honesty of Chitose's personality is incredibly refreshing and likeable. Her development, as she grows and learns about what it takes to remain in a cut-throat professional environment is easily reminiscent of the growing pains anyone would experience when first trying a new job; flattery, cynicism, professionalism and laziness are all qualities that Chitose's character has to experience and develop through and it is what places her at fourth place in our Best Protagonist category.

The underdog that no one believed in takes that trope and manage to make it better than many have before. He takes the risks that you expect a MC like him should and he takes them in a way that makes the audience cheer for him. Even when he was a weakling, Midoriya was always someone you could see take a leader role when things got serious, that became even more obvious when he got his powers and that really helps him grow as a character for us viewers. He also managed to make some natural connections to the entire cast which a leader should be able to. He is still though a type of character we have seen many times before which makes him slightly less interesting, even if it seems like that he might be able to be one of the best in his character genre we didn't really see that in season one. The first season was a prologue, and with some more development in the upcoming season/seasons we might see Midoriya be higher up the list.

After watching Rakugo, the feeling the viewers are left with is that they personally met Kikuhiko, became his close friend and watched all of his life with special attention.

That's not random, great well written characters are often relatable to the viewer, they appear to us as real people, not just fiction characters, and Kikuhiko is the best example of that in 2016.

His growth as a person throughout his life is the main focus of Rakugo and it does wonders for his character, we see him struggle against problems every human being struggle with, like friends, sexuality, and a career, all of that presented in Kiku's own point of view which deepens the audience's understanding of his persona even further, showcasing layers of a personality so varied and complex that we can only qualify it as impressive.

In the story, Subaru Natsuki is an ordinary high school student who is lost in an alternate world, where he is rescued by a beautiful, silver-haired girl. He stays near her to return the favor, but the destiny she is burdened with is more than Subaru can imagine. Enemies attack one by one, and both of them are killed. He then finds out he has the power to rewind death, back to the time he first came to this world. But only he remembers what has happened since.

The story revolves around "Mob," a boy who will explode if his emotional capacity reaches 100%. This boy with psychic powers earned his nickname "Mob" because he does not stand out among other people. He keeps his psychic powers bottled up so he can live normally, but if his emotional level reaches 100, something will overwhelm his entire body.

Kumiko is wonderfully ordinary. In fact, she is so "normal" that she often portrays herself as indifferent to fit in, much like many real teenagers do. However, small details in her characterisation, such as her self-doubt and her obsession with vanity, all mask a girl who truly cares about her surroundings. She initially seems indifferent, but, throughout both seasons, she matures into a girl who is willingly ready to be involved in other people's' lives. So, as a girl who focuses on being mundane only to find herself thrust out of her comfort-zone, Kumiko is the perfect foil for Reina, a girl who focuses on being special only to find acceptance from others. Kumiko's characterization also owes heaps to Tomoyo Kurosawa's beautifully grounded performance. Tomoyo handles both drama and comedy with graceful ease, allowing Kumiko to feel like a living, breathing individual who excels as the emotional glue for Hibike Euphonium's vast supporting cast.

Everybody loves a good cynical jerk, and Kazuma is the ideal guy for that role. Unfortunately, being a jerk is just about all there is to him. All of Kazuma's interactions are exactly the same; one of the girls does something stupid, and Kazuma yells at them for being useless. His relationship with each of them is exactly the same, and none of it ever changes. The show demonstrates that Kazuma can really shine when it mixes up the formula and puts him in the comedic driver's seat, like during the succubus episode, but that very rarely happens. So while Kazuma is undeniably a funny guy, he simply can't stand on the same playing field as the other nominees.

In a similar vein, Swim Swim was an excellent villain tragically in need of a protagonist to antagonize. Until the final episode, she never really acts as an obstacle for the cast to overcome, instead working more as a force of nature, striking when they least expect it. While murdering fan favorites over and over again is an excellent way to get the viewer to hate her, she doesn’t exhibit any of the qualities of an Antagonist that the others on this list do. If she had been in a better show capable of utilizing her character design, and we’d gotten more development from her, she could easily have scored top marks in this list. As it is, she’s better used as a lightning rod.

Fango is the one character who didn’t really belong in this competition. He’s a surprisingly likeable character, with a wild unpredictable streak that is put to good use in 91 Days to mix up the stuffy Mobsters. But ultimately, he’s not even as evil, ambitious, or cunning as the protagonists in the show. And those guys are stuffy mobsters. He is an excellently designed character used to his full capacity in a well-designed show. But even Swim Swim makes a better antagonist.

Satou provided a very close competition to Kira. Satou has it all, a Commanding presence, Terrifying abilities, and an almost Lovable personality. Unfortunately, he was held back by the show he was in. Ajin’s second season escalated too far too fast, and Satou suffered from it.  The show needed a villain capable of standing on the global scale, requiring Satou to become something he wasn’t well suited for, while simultaneously separating him from the Protagonists.  It’s a testament to just how excellent he was that he placed so highly even with the deck stacked against him… in true Satou fashion.

Betelgeuse Romanee-Conti is one hell of a character. Even his name has an extravagance attached to it, a quality that his voice actor only further reinforced with his stellar performance. Unfortunately, being an interesting character doesn’t instantly translate into being a good antagonist. He never really has a chance to stand in the main antagonist spotlight until the final 2 episodes, being usurped by the white whale and Subaru’s own self-loathing. And his performance in the last 2 episodes just wasn’t good enough to push past Satou, much less Kira.  Truly Slothful.

While not the perfect Antagonist, Kira is by far the best antagonist in 2016.  His desire to lead a "normal" life is unique and interesting, and a lower key, stealthy villain is equally unexpected, especially in a season of JoJo. From terrifying attacks like "Bites the Dust", low key quirks like his nail obsession, and a surprisingly compelling home narrative. Kira constantly performs far above expectations and is a joy to watch.  From introduction to conclusion Kira was a Blast.

Nishioka is the engine of Fune wo Amu and the main driving force in Majime's development. His confident personality contrasted Majime's calm demeanor beautifully, and the way these characters ended up inspiring each other is fantastically written. In 11 episodes you see him develop from a guy that doesn't much care about his job to a vital aspect of the editorial family. He's a very genuine and human character who still learns and grows as an adult in a workplace society, but also develops outside of that world with the romance he develops with Miyoshi. The fact that he takes a less vital position in the final moments of the series however puts him down from being a contender for the #1 spot.

Papika's dedication to her role is appreciated but honestly a bit repetitive. It's nice to see that her story fully commits to the idea it presents from beginning to end but that also leads it to lack any kind of variety. Her love for Cocona felt like just pandering at first but overtime it became more developed. Therefore she still has a well deserved spot among the top 5 contestants thanks to the chemistry she has with the show's protagonist.

Hikari Kohinata (Pikari) is our adorable and bubbly deuteragonist. She's a genki girl with some fun quirks and comedic reaction faces. She uses her outward personality as a means to deal with her own fear and anxieties. This makes her especially adept in helping the shy and quiet Teko. Much of the series revolves around their friendship and Pikari's influence in helping Teko break out of her shell. One enviable aspect to Pikari is how she regularly seeks out the happiness and little joys in life, something which ultimately rubs off on much of the cast. Unfortunately while Pikari does a lot for Teko, she herself goes through little development as it takes a backseat, leaving much to be desired. Because of this Pikari doesn't feel as complex as other nominees, and for some, her bouncy personality can come across as a bit annoying.

Chidori is an overall pretty well-written character, who fails to stand out as a proper main character. She lacks relevance to the overall narrative and stands out only due to her personality and role as the childhood friend. Her infatuation with the protagonist isn't very well explained, and her selfishness makes her unlikable to most. Despite this, she is a rather charming character with enough character complexity to make her worthy of a nomination, though she cannot be ranked any higher due to her lack of importance in the story of Kiznaiver.

Everyone has regrets in life. So who wouldn't take the chance to change the past if given the opportunity? When sixteen-year-old Takamiya Naho receives a mysterious letter, claiming to be from her twenty-seven-year-old self, her life is suddenly thrown into flux. The letter tells her that a new transfer student by the name of Naruse Kakeru will be joining her class, and to keep her eye on him. But why? Naho must decide what to make of the letter and its cryptic warning, and what it means not only for her future, but for Kakeru's as well.

What do you get when you live the life of a deity, never having to worry about much other than your rank and the deific job you're supposed to do? Selfish, stupid, and inept. Dragged into another world by a cruel candidate for reincarnation, Aqua is desperately dependent upon Kazuma to succeed but too naive to know how to work toward that success. It's this character flaw that makes her very divisive. She's incredibly abrasive, whiny, and stupid, and this can definitely turn someone away. On the other hand, she meshes perfectly with the flawed party she's in and is a great source for gags if that's your kind of joke.

Ohta played a solid straight man for Tanaka in this SoL comedy. Though some may see his kindness as too much or even detrimental to his friends, his empathy and motherly instincts adds a unique twist to that trope. He stands out from the cast as well as add to the comfy feeling of the show. Along with little quirks such as his fondness for sweets and his fear of ghosts, this gave him a little more depth and personality than Aqua. Ohta provides good support for comedic situations and set the mood of the characters around him, but at times it feels like he is just there, and can be replaced by another character. Ultimately, he is a gag character with not much depth, and there is no justification for him to be ranked any higher in this list.

Writing a complex character that's serious, pessimistic and down-to-earth is one thing, but writing a complex character that's cheerful, lazy and open is another. With his loud, boisterous nature and true passion for Rakugo, Sukeroku commands every scene he’s in. But the real masterstroke of his character is the subtlety with which his love for Rakugo is contrasted with the depression that takes over his life. With the major framing device of Rakugo Shinjuu being Kikuhiko’s reflections on his performing life, it’s no surprise that the relationship and contrast between the two was the biggest reason why we loved Sukeroku. The tragedy of a talented performer who inspired the same passion in our main character but lost his way, and the redemption he found when his friend helped him rediscover his own passion was a character arc we found just too compelling for us to put Sukeroku anywhere on our list.

It's the year 1999, 11 years after Jotaro Kujo's desperate fight against Dio in Egypt. Jotaro meets with Josuke Higashikata, the illegitimate son of his grandfather Joseph Joestar. He discovers that Josuke also has the same "Stand" power and that a new threat is surfacing in Morioh City.

Asuka's character comes into clearer focus than ever before in the second season of Hibike! Euphonium. Her personality is revealed at a steady pace throughout the course of the show, covering details such as her emotional distance from others and her passion for the euphonium. Her arc with Kumiko in the later episodes is intimate and emotional, and her resulting growth is well-earned. Asuka takes a larger role in this season compared to the first, but there are times where her role within the show is diminished, or where her character arc is overly simple or predictable. These negatives were the jury's main reason for placing her below the top picks in third; but with a clear positive consensus amongst jury members, we felt that Asuka was one of the best characters of the year with well-developed actions, convictions, and growth throughout the entirety of Hibike! Euphonium 2.

Kazuma Satou, professional NEET, dies a rather inglorious death and is given two possibilities by the rather obnoxious goddess Aqua: continue on to Heaven or reincarnate into another world.

Deciding to not pass upon the dream of every gamer, Kazuma decides to start a new life in a fantasy world but not before forcing the annoying goddess to accompany him.

In a show that's dominated by psychics, ghosts, and all around bad dudes, Reigen Arataka manages to be the perfect foil to all of them by virtue of his sheer normalcy and morality. This fast talking conman with a heart of gold feels so great because he's not just our frame of reference as viewers, but also because he's constantly playing the straight man in a show where everyone else is batshit crazy. More than that, his philosophy of "everyone's equal, so be the best person you can" is one that, many similar shows flat out overlook. Reigen and his worldview are half the reason why the show really ticks. However, what prevented him from taking the number two or three spots was the fact that he was conspicuously absent from the middle of the show, and overall he didn't really have much character development.

What everyone loved about Miyokichi was how fantastically well written she was. Everything about her, from her dialogue, to her relationships with Kikuhiko and Sukeroku, was amazing. She was far more human than every other character nominated, and had enough of a character arc that if she had more screentime she could qualify as a lead herself. Miyokichi was vivid and complex in a way she didn’t need to be, but both she and Rakugo Shinjuu at large are better for the loving amount of detail and attention that she was written with.

Sachiko Fujinuma is a sharp and observant mother that provides Satoru with a very warm and loving environment to grow up in. Something that is reflected by his sense of justice and morality. Unfortunately there's not much more that can be added about Sachiko's character. She experiences little development over the course of the series and lacks both history and identity. She ends up being fairly flat and heavily defined by her role as a mother, and due to her limited screen time she comes off as more of an aid to Satoru and less as an individual. Sachiko has some great moments but in the end there's just not enough to her character to warrant ranking her higher.

Throughout Flying Witch, Akane often acts as the source of comic relief in a wide variety of scenes and situations. Laid back and casual with magic, her lax approach to the world often results in amusing and entertaining trouble for the other characters. But she also represents an important part of the world in Flying Witch: like Makoto, Akane straddles the line between the mundane and magical and is an important part of making magic feel like a natural part of the world. Her character doesn’t change much across Flying Witch’s 12 episodes, nor is she an emotionally complex character - her main trait is simply “Makoto’s free-spirited witch older sister”. While that lack of depth brought her down in the jury’s eyes, we still felt positive about Akane’s character overall and thought she was a key part to the world of Flying Witch.

Nakajima Atsushi was kicked out of his orphanage, and now he has no place to go and no food. While he is standing by a river, on the brink of starvation, he rescues a man whimsically attempting suicide. That man is Dazai Osamu, and he and his partner Kunikida are members of a very special detective agency. They have supernatural powers, and deal with cases that are too dangerous for the police or the military. They're tracking down a tiger that has appeared in the area recently, around the time Atsushi came to the area. The tiger seems to have a connection to Atsushi, and by the time the case is solved, it is clear that Atsushi's future will involve much more of Dazai and the rest of the detectives!

Natsuki showed some great initiative this season by helping her friend get back into the club, while trying on her own to not fallback from the rest of the club. Her interactions with Yuuko "Ribbon-chan" also made a return and were greater than before. The biggest appeal of her was her charming personality and her nature to support others, even when it was some kind hearted teasing. But after these few interactions she kinda melded into the background as the main cast took over.

Wilhelm is very charming in some aspects. The idea of a badass old knight is pretty awesome and his backstory is quite endearing. However he does lack in a lot of aspects that would make him a good supporting character. While he’s the main face of action in the series he tends to lack any role in the series beyond being a warrior. His personality is pretty flat and as a character he’s almost solely defined by his role. He feels underdeveloped and lacking in significance which ultimately lands him in the bottom spot.

Yayaka made an interesting foil to Cocona and Papika throughout the runtime of Flip Flappers. Her whole plotline was a ton of fun to watch, and her almost tsundere attitude towards the two, especially Cocona, was a real treat. The struggle she faced as both Cocona’s friend and enemy was a great source of tension from within her character, and her changing motivations were justified by her emotional complexity. The problem with her was that at times it felt like she was less of a character and more of a plot device to move the story along through her interactions with the main duo.

Following their participation at the Inter-High, the Karasuno High School volleyball team attempts to refocus their efforts, aiming to conquer the Spring tournament instead.

When they receive an invitation from long-standing rival Nekoma High, Karasuno agrees to take part in a large training camp alongside many notable volleyball teams in Tokyo and even some national level players. By playing with some of the toughest teams in Japan, they hope not only to sharpen their skills, but also come up with new attacks that would strengthen them. Moreover, Hinata and Kageyama attempt to devise a more powerful weapon, one that could possibly break the sturdiest of blocks.

Facing what may be their last chance at victory before the senior players graduate, the members of Karasuno's volleyball team must learn to settle their differences and train harder than ever if they hope to overcome formidable opponents old and new—including their archrival Aoba Jousai and its world-class setter Tooru Oikawa.

The comedic, ostensibly superficial nature of Konosuba allows it to have a cast that is not full of the most authentic, profound or well-developed characters, but rather an ensemble cast full of the most fun ones. A horribly perverted, disillusioned teenage hero protagonist is complimented by an explosion-loving witch, an unfathomably dense and despicable goddess, and a masochistic, lustful knight that all come together to form a cast-ensemble that is up there with the best when it comes to chemistry and entertainment, even if the groups truthfully dumb characters may not be everyone’s cup of tea.

Kiznaiver is a show with a wide variety of clichés and tropés on display which, while may not appeal to many, are used in a way that allow the cast to interact naturally and it eases up on the writing on the characters so that productivity can be placed elsewhere such as the incredibly gorgeous character designs.

There is a reason Kiznaiver is last on this list however and it’s because some character motivations simply exist due to convenience of the plot, the chemistry while good never develops and as such is something left to be desired and the same goes for the characters as individuals. The characters were strong and unique enough to make it onto the list but quite subpar comparatively to the other nominees.

Tanaka-kun was a fun and enjoyable anime, and the lovable characters sure helped in providing a fun experience to the viewers, The Tanaka-kun+Oota dynamics were fantastic, to the point that the anime could be just focused in those two fooling around and still be a really fun to watch, and  it's even better when you can also add to them the other great recurrent characters: Miyano, the human bullet that can't stop being hyperactive, even if she wants to be the opposite and is amazed by Tanaka-kun's laziness, Shiraishi, who wants to live a glorious high school life so she tries her hardest to be a popular school idol type girl, when in reality she rather fits into the dweeb category, which makes for a fantastic contrast, Echizen, a girl and childhood friend of Oota that tries to be a delinquent, and adorably fails at it... all of them add a lot of fun and variety to this anime, and the interactions between them and the main duo are really entertaining.

The thing is that, while still being a solid and likeable cast for a slice of life/comedy, it was just that, none of the characters but Shiraishi got some development through the duration of the anime, and the characters in general didn't hold up to the level of the higher rated nominees, so while the judges appreciated the characters, the competition was just superior for this award.

nominees.altname: JoJo Part IV: Diamond is Unbreakable
nominees.writeup:
JoJo is back with a new cast of characters and more action, what makes the ensemble of JoJo special is three things, interaction, fun and JoJo-esque characterization. The interaction between the characters is very well made as it progresses smoothly and naturally depending on the relationship between the characters, there’s a lot sense to make in the interaction and it moves forward by using all characters rather than only having a select few speak.

The characterization is another strong point of JoJo as well but not in the traditional sense, JoJo has always done as it pleases with the characters and it still does, but it works fantastically and adds to the flair that makes up the insanity that is JoJo which is why it’s so glorious, but most of all the cast is very fun, they’re all amazingly fun to follow as very modern teenage punks, very relatable to those of us who grew up in the 90’s following the TV-shows from that era, and while doing this still keeping the JoJo-esque mysterious aura. Very strong ensemble cast in general from Diamond is Unbreakable hence it takes our 2nd place.

Hibike! Euphoniums ensemble cast shines very well due to the excellent dynamic brought to our attention by following Kumiko’s point of view, Kumiko as a main character is someone who is very relatable and very real to us while sustaining that air of fantasy that makes anime so interesting, Due to her curiosity we dip into various ensemble members dramas like Mizore & Asuka, The ensemble of Hibike was always very good but this season especially excelled at focusing on the relationship between Mizore, Yuuko & Nozomi, Kumiko and her sister as well as the senpai-kouhai relationship of Asuka and Kumiko.

There are however some downsides to only seeing the story through one perspective which is why Euphonium fell to 3rd but still a very strong showing.

To make a good sport show you must have one thing and that's great characters, Haikyuu has just that. In an all around brilliant cast you get to know each member of the Karasuno school. The character development in this show is amazing, you can feel how much closer the characters gets with every episode. Not only are the Karasuno cast developed, but the show also manage to make their opponents into some great characters. It’s amazing how much the show manage to develop the characters when they are in games, they are able to make the enemies of Karasuno into characters you really love, the biggest candidate for this is Oikawa who is the Karsunos biggest enemy but is still someone you can’t hate. 

The show then proceed to show us why it’s the best cast of the year when it manage to bring us new faces in season three but still is able to bring out some amazing characters/development for it and at the same time make it feel like we have always had those characters in the cast. To make the final boss into such a lovely bunch is no easy feat, but Haikyuu does it perfectly. With a vast cast of characters you always get surprised how Haikyuu manage to make each encounter with a new character into something even more satisfying than the last, to never fail to bring us an exciting character into the hype show that is Haikyuu we are gladly giving it the first spot in the ensemble cast category.

The Gomorins are untraditional mascots in several ways. Most obviously, they're not the usual cute, fluffy animal designs you normally expect - murderous civil servants is definitely an unusual role for mascots. Furthermore, their inability to talk or emote is quite limiting - even Pikachu can say its name in a variety of tones!

That being said, the Gomorins absolutely embrace and enhance the zany atmosphere of Kiznaiver and serve as an excellent abstract stand-in for all of the forces propelling the characters. Their design may lack immediate widespread appeal, but it is unquestionably unique and even incorporates the series' logo, as well. 

While we would have liked to see more usage of the Gomorins in the marketing for Kiznaiver, it is a safe assumption that if this became a franchise on the scale of Pokemon there would be parades of Gomorin costumes just like there are of Pikachu.

Timothy is cute, well-dressed, fairly unique in overall design, and occupies a character role within Anne Happy that is perfect for a mascot. However, Anne Happy does not really use Timothy as a mascot - he has little bearing in any marketing or merchandising and doesn't generally act as an ambassador of the series. Thus, we felt that while Timothy has great mascot potential, he never had the opportunity to become a real one.

The show's story revolves around Yūri Katsuki, who carried all of Japan's hopes on his shoulders to win at the Gran Prix Finale ice skating competition, but suffered a crushing defeat. He returns home to Kyushu and half feels like he wants to retire, and half feels like he wants to continue ice skating. With those mixed feelings swirling inside him, he confines himself inside his parents house. Suddenly the five-time consecutive world championship ice skater Victor Nikiforov appears before him, and along with him is Yuri Plisetsky, a young Russian figure skater who is already defeating his seniors. Victor and both Yuris take up the challenge on an unprecedented Gran Prix series.

Since he was young, a teenage boy named Natsume Takashi has been able to see youkai, but keeping this ability a secret has now become a heavy burden for him and has made his life difficult.

This begins to change when Takashi inherits his grandmother's "Book of Friends." He discovers that she, Natsume Reiko, shared the same ability as him and starts to understand why he was always targeted by both good and bad youkai.

After learning the true meaning behind the Book of Friends, which allows him to manipulate the spirits listed within its pages, Natsume undertakes a journey with his bodyguard, the infamous spirit Madara, to free the spirits of their contracts with Reiko.

Much like Timothy, Uexkull's cute and fluffy design gives it widespread appeal which *could* be used well as a mascot, but the series has no interest in capitalizing on this potential. Furthermore, Uexkull is itself overshadowed by the presence of Bu-chan, another pet-like creature.

For 99% of you reading this, the very moment that you read "Bananya" the winner list you could instantly picture (possibly involuntarily) Bananya in full detail, even if you've never seen a trailer, let alone an episode, of the series. That right there is all you really need to know: Bananya is such a good mascot that its recognizability even outweighs its series' actual popularity. Can there be any greater testament to the success of a mascot than that?

This isn't some accident or just some meme, though. Bananya's visual design is universally appealing and its conceptualization is both extremely simple (just a cat in a banana, really) but at the same time it is unquestionably unique. The titular Bananya also stands as the shepherd to a whole range of other cat-in-banana characters from the series which open up additional marketing and merchandising options for the franchise.

This cat has got it in the ~~bag~~ banana.

Dimple is on the bottom of these nominations because we didn't see him as a mascot at all (and if we weren't bound to include a certain number of popular candidates he wouldn't be here at all). Dimple has almost none of the characteristics of a mascot. He isn't aesthetically unique or appealing, he has no role in the marketing of the series, and he doesn't serve as any sort of ambassador for Mob Psycho 100. He's a character in the series, not a mascot at all.

As a cute anthropomorphic creature that acts as a sidekick, advisor and granter of powers to a magical girl, Puck follows in the same traditions as many classic anime mascots such as Luna, Kerberos, or Kyuubey. His design is appealing, but also fairly commonplace, while his active role in certain events within the series also tend to depict him as more of a character than a true mascot. Biggest hindrance of all, is that Puck is not the anthropomorphic guide and friend of the series' main character, only of Emilia, which severely limits his relevance in presenting himself as an ambassador of the franchise.

sections.name: Production
sections.blurb: These awards are given to the shows that have displayed exceptional performance in technical areas. From visuals to sound to OP and ED, every award in this section showcases a different aspect of the process of anime production.

nominees.writeup: Concrete Revolutio: The Last Song could be considered this year's king of effect animation. Jirou's flames, Kikko's magic, and the fantastic array of different superhuman abilities make for a spectacle of beauty. ConRevo excels at its action fights, some being animated by Yutaka Nakimura, famous for his astonishing impact frames and iconic cubic debris destruction. And it's luckily not just the effects, but the entirety of every fight scene brimming with amazing animation from how the characters move to the brilliance of each explosion. But while the fight scenes in ConRevo are some of the best work this year, the rest of the series does not feature anything truly remarkable in terms of animation, making it a clear show of highs and lows.

nominees.writeup: Sansha Sanyou is perhaps one of the standout shows of its genre with the smoothest and well-crafted animation. Every single scene is given so much love and attention to detail that it's hard not to be impressed. While Doga Kobo is well known for having well animated shows, Sansha Sanyou takes it up a notch. This is directly typified by animating the cats in ones, and exponentially increasing their adorableness. The character movements, subtle effects, and sheer fluidity of every facet in the show creates a pleasant experience that is rarely seen elsewhere.

nominees.writeup: As the world is in the middle of an industrial revolution, a monster appears that cannot be defeated unless its heart, which is protected by a layer of iron, is pierced. By infecting humans with its bite, the monster can create aggressive and undead creatures known as Kabane. On the island Hinomoto, located in the far east, people have built stations to shelter themselves from these creatures. People access the station, as well as transport wares between them, with the help of a locomotive running on steam, called Hayajiro. Ikoma, a boy who lives in the Aragane station and helps to build Hayajiro, creates his own weapon called Tsuranukizutsu in order to defeat the creatures. One day, as he waits for an opportunity to use his weapon, he meets a girl named Mumei, who is excused from the mandatory Kabane inspection. During the night, Ikuma meets Mumei again as he sees Hayajiro going out of control. The staff on the locomotive has turned into the creatures. The transformation sequences are detailed and smooth, serve as a great call back to the magical girl genre's heydays. On top of all this, the camera is almost always rotating while multiple objects are in motion, making the quality of the animation even more incredible. Between the fights, the characters are expressive, and the special effects when exploring Pure Illusion are bring the myriad of fantasy worlds to life. However, there was an unfortunate dip in quality during the last couple of episodes, where the animation and effects are smooth-ish, but weaker, and the drawings of less important characters and scenes are noticeably simpler. nominees.writeup: Due its nature of travelling to various worlds, Flip Flappers has the natural advantage of being able to set up exquisite scenery that is both beautiful as well as being key to understanding the show's core themes and the mental states of its characters. Whereas Hibike's cinematography shines from emulating those of live action, Flip Flappers comes from using camera angles and scenery to recreate optical illusions and famous paintings. Those camera angles, while arguably not as good as Occultic;9's, convey a sense of suffocation when characters are closed off, and of heroism and admiration when those barriers are broken down. And while the use of lighting is not as dynamic as with the two other shows in the top 3, Flip Flappers's use of color is superb and there are still great scenes where the shadows help to convey the duality of the human conscious. Finally, when talking about cinematography, it is hard not to overlook the brilliant display in Episode 5. The colors, the repetition of scenes and the lighting all come together in a perfect mix to set the atmosphere for the episode. The use of camera is always close to make the viewer feel trapped and obscure information to create a sense of dread. The long hallways shots and and imposing shots of the eerily red clock tower give us a taste of the diminutiveness and powerlessness that our heroines feel when trapped in the defense mechanism of the Amorphous. When they finally exit from Pure Illusion, a rippling, reflective shot of their own clock tower over a puddle is there as a bittersweet reminder that the problems represented by the world they were in are not completely gone. Admittedly there are some low moments (relative to the rest of the nominees) in Flip Flapper's cinematography, but in it's highs, Flip Flappers leverages it not only to accentuate its storytelling and themes, but actively add onto them.

nominees.writeup:
So an android, a magical girl, an obake, a hyper-nationalist Superman, Optimus Prime, and Godzilla walk into a bar...

Concrete Revolutio has one of the largest and most diverse casts of any anime, from little robot-girl Earth-chan to building-sized alien Grosse Augen, to olympic skiiers, numerous beastly Kaiju, aliens and much, much more. These characters and creatures may have innumerable distinct origins and influences, but Concrete Revolutio's excellent character design both keeps all of these charactesr looking totally unique and ensures that all of them fit in just fine with the show's half-real-half-cartoon general art style.

Additionally, many of the characters sport numerous outfits and/or transformations. In particular, as the show changes from the idealistic early 1960s to a later, vastly more cynical time period the characters' outfits and appearances change in tandem with their changing social roles: Government supporters don police-like uniforms whilst outlaws grow more visually rebellious and individualistic.

Most impressive of all, however, is how Concrete Revolutio visually incorporates its real-world character inspirations. Nearly all of the main and secondary characters' designs are homages to the real-world characters that they are based upon (and whom they've replaced in the ConRevo universe). Earth-chan looks much like a combination of Astro Boy and Space Ace, Grosse Augen takes after Ultraman, Megasshin is Kikaider, etc.

nominees.writeup:
With characters frantically vaulting across the screen in everything from dark tunnels to brightly lit landscapes and camera-work that pans and spins around in every action scene, Kabaneri's character design faces a difficult challenge of ensuring that all of its characters are easy to visually track against a multitude of diverse backgrounds, even at breakneck speeds and without a rooted audience perspective. Furthermore, it all has to fit within an art style that uses high-contrast shading, occasional high-saturation colourings, and integrates CG with its 2D animation.

Kabaneri attacks this titanic challenge with grace and aplomb. The main characters feature multiple colours and contrasting shades in their designs (e.g. Ikoma sports green hair, blue pants, yellow gas tanks, a red cape and exposed skin tones) that make their flips and turns easy to follow against any background, and even the kabani themselves sport glowing streaks or bits of coloured clothing that make them easier to track than just a grey/brown blob. The paletting choices keep all the colouring from looking cartoony, and there's even digital make-up effects being used to add detail to more dramatic scene without compromising the designs.

However, these design strengths are undermined by a lack of contrast between the characters' designs, especially amongst the recurring secondary characters, and several unusual costuming choices that don't fully fit the theme of the series. Additionally, the way the designs can support the action is frequently undermined by the digital effects - fires, smoke, darkened scenes, etc - which reduce the visual contrast.
