nominees.writeup: We felt that no other OP in 2016 was as good of a love letter to its respective series than Great Days was. Along with nailing the conventional criteria for what makes an outstanding anime intro, Great Days also shows some incredible creativity through what very well may be the single best OP alteration we have ever seen. This completely unexpected and marvellously entertaining twist shows a level of pre-planning and ambition that most OPs don't even try to breach. The result is a rich and dynamic credit sequence that perfectly encapsulates both the story's heroes and its main villain simultaneously. Even for a very divisive category like this one, we found it easy to agree on this placement.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Yasufumi Soejima

Performed by Karen Aoki & Daisuke Hasegawa

nominees.writeup:
99 is yet another one that had the jury very split, we all agreed on it deserving a spot but there were a lot of disagreements of where to place it. It has an incredible amount of manga references which is really fun and it looks gorgeous with some fantastic, even psychedelic animation, on top of that 99 very rarely makes any hard cut transitions, which feels incredibly unique and makes it a visual standout. In addition, the OP captures Mob's character super well and explains his fears and limits and does various exploration into his relationships.

However, the sheer amount manga references were a bit of a double edged sword in our eyes, and there were some parts that were a bit too visually cluttered as well.

Even though the lyrics might not be the most thought out ones the counting is genius for the show and the song is very catchy, 99 will be an opening to remember for sure.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Yuzuru Tachikawa

Performed by MOB CHOIR

nominees.writeup: Fighter is an ED that's incredibly fitting for a show like 3-Gatsu no Lion, and the song and visuals fit the atmosphere of the show beautifully. Where the OP represents Rei's depressed state by showing him drowning in a deep river, this uses similar themes to show us Rei being a "fighter" and aspiring to get out of the lonely and dark depths. The recurring themes of water are shown not only in the setting but also in the transitions and backgrounds making every aspect of this ED complement each other perfectly. The visuals are a great match to the track by Bump of Chicken making for an ED that's symbolic, atmospheric and oh so impressive. Fighter is a great example of an ED where every part works together and matches in a way that makes it even greater than the sum of its parts, and making for an absolutely fantastic second place.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Ryosuke Nakamura

Performed by BUMP OF CHICKEN

nominees.writeup: At first glance, Hajimari no Sokudo might seem like a strange pick for a position this relatively high on the list. While the opinions on this ED differed quite wildly between judges it ended up taking sixth spot. Hajimari no Sokudo shows us a lot of things in a very subtle way. Its visuals consist of various carefully drawn and animated shots of the main four girls holding bouquets of flowers standing in front of a white background. At first glance the ED might seem standard but the beauty of it lies in the subtleties, as the bouquet each girl is holding and the flowers shown represent their personality, role in the story and dreams in a very subtle way. Each flower has a meaning that nods to one of these aspects making the bouquets shown each tell us a lot about these characters, and with the added factor that flowers play a role in Kiznaiver itself these bouquets hold a lot of meaning and foreshadowing. On top of that the shots, while simple. are carefully composed to give nods to events in the series or show us part of their personality, making for a simple yet meaningful ED with a beautiful song to go with it.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Yuki Watanabe

Performed by Sangatsu no Phantasia

nominees.writeup: Vivace is just plain fun. After a drama heavy episode of Hibike, having such an upbeat song to close things off feels surprisingly cathartic, especially when considering that they use the VA's for the song itself. Along with that, the sequence is gorgeous and visually playful, especially seeing how they animate hair when the girls are running. It also wins major props for telling its own story about finding Kumiko finding joy through music, mirroring much of her arc throughout the first season of Hibike. Ultimately though, the sequence lacks substance when compared to most others on the list, and fails to add much of anything to the show proper beyond being a catchy and charismatic ED. It's above-average production values and playful style earn it a spot on the list, but the lack of meat on its bones ranks it here among the other especially great nominees.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Haruka Fujita

Performed by Kitauji Quartet

nominees.writeup: Hatsunetsu follows a narrative very akin to the events that it accompanied in the show. It tells a story of vengeance fueled by determination as Karasuno gets fired up to face off for the second time against Aoba Johsai. The art style was very clean, using black-and-white with just a touch of colours on the team's jersey's and ball to make them pop. The song is great with a slow but steady ramp-up to the payoff where our protagonists"snap" into full colour and are on the court ready to get their revenge. At times it seemed like there was a lack of stuff happening since scenes lingered for a bit too long and tended to look similar to the last. Hatsunetsu's strong narrative and bangin' song earns it a spot on this list but the mildly boring direction don't help it place higher than the EDs above it.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Naoyoshi Shiotani

Performed by tacica
Performed by NICO Touches the Walls

Directed by Yuichiro Hayashi, Sayo Yamamoto

Performed by Wataru Hatano

Directed by Haruhiko Mikimoto

Performed by Aimer × chelly

nominees.writeup:
I Want You shows the various stand users throughout the town of Morioh, adding more and more to the sequence as the series goes on, demonstrating the growth of the town's character as well. The scrolling, one shot look of the ED is definitely unique, and there are clever transitions added on for certain characters (Rohan mainly) that work well while keeping the unique look. Finally, the song is super chill and a great way to unwind after an intense stand battle.

This isn't to say that the ED is perfect, however. The scrolling of the camera doesn't always work, especially as more elements are added to the ED in the final legs of the series, creating a sense of visual clutter that can be difficult to follow. In addition, it lacks substance beyond the characters, with no real symbolism or foreshadowing to speak of when compared to the DiU OPs. Ultimately, the balance between I Want You's strengths and flaws make it end up at a respectable 7th place.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Yasufumi Soejima

Performed by Savage Garden

nominees.writeup: Chiisana Boukensha was a wonderful ED which fit KonoSuba perfectly. The music really gives you the feeling that you're an adventurer who has just returned home from a day of exploration and fighting, which is what Kazuma and the gang spend their days doing. The characters and the setting are fleshed out in ways that the actual series with its abundance of comedy doesn't have the screentime for, and the time lapse shots of the village are truly stunning. Despite all of this, we decided that at times the ED was rather simple at times and left out some key characters and details which is why Chiisana Boukensha wasn't placed higher.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Takaomi Kanasaki

Performed by Sora Amamiya, Rie Takahashi & Ai Kayano

nominees.writeup: With an emotional song and interesting animations Sore wa Chiisana really captures the whole thriller experience of Erased. It gives us some well-made references to the show and handles the pacing between song/animation in a satisfying way when the music goes from slow to fast and the animation keeps up with it. The artistic nature of the ED suit well with how the way Erased is directed and animated. It is a great ending for having as a gatekeeper of the top 5 of the year.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Masashi Ishihama

Performed by Sayuri

nominees.writeup: Refrain Boy makes its mark by being fantastic in terms of visuals, it has a strong narrative following the relationship between Mob and Reigen but mostly of all it looks amazing. Everything in the entire opening except for a single thing is made by using oil paint on glass which is a very unique method that takes a lot of work, but made the ending look as fantastic as it did. In addition, the ED expands a lot on Reigen's character and keeps him in the audience's mind when the plot moves away from him in the middle. While the lack of substance beyond "a day in the life of Reigen" keeps it from going higher, the wonderful animation and execution on its target goal earn it a hard fought third place.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Miyo Sato

Performed by ALL OFF

nominees.writeup:
Styx Helix is a fantastic song that captures Subaru's character and what he strives and fights for very well, it captures the mental horror he goes through and the breakdown of his psyche, it's also a very significant tone setter for the show.
It portrays the relationship between Emilia of Subaru strongly with its visuals but aside from that the visuals are largely boring and insignificant, You could argue that the snowflakes bear heavy meaning on the vast amount of possibilities available for Subaru but even then it doesn't stand out much comparatively to the other nominees on here.

All in all the audio for Styx Helix is a very strong point while the visuals are somewhat stale to make it a top tier ending which causes Styx Helix to place 9th out of the 10 endings as despite of it all, it's still a good ending that definitely deserves a spot on the list.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Tatsuya Koyanagi

Performed by MYTH&ROID

nominees.writeup: FLIP FLAP FLIP FLAP is pure enchantment. The whimsical vibe that the ED instills from TO-MAS's song and from the cute images is the perfect way to wean the audience off from the last 20 minutes of adventures they experienced. In addition, the ED is the best use of split screen visuals seen this year, pulling your attention between the lavishly designed and storybook-esque fairytale panel on the top, and the cute antics between Papika and Cocona on the bottom, encouraging multiple watches to catch all the subtle details between the two. This visual presentation reflects upon the show's main narrative focus (the dynamic between the leads and their adventures), reinforcing it in a cute and charming way that feels completely unique and absolutely excellent. This ED defines its respective show in a more memorable way than anything else in 2016 and was ended up being a runaway favorite.
nominees.staff:
Directed by Kiyotaka Oshiyama

Performed by TO-MAS ft. Chima

nominees.writeup: While Takahiro Sakurai's depiction of Reigen was great, all it did is fit his character greatly and we think that Reigen was better expressed through his character traits, than the performance of the VA, which put him at the bottom of the list.
nominees.staff: Takahiro Sakurai

nominees.writeup: Fukushima Jun lends his voice well to Kazuma, enhancing the comedy in Konosuba quite nicely. He gives us an "Everyone around me is a moron" attitude and portrays well how tired Kazuma is with all the shenanigans that his party gets into. Comedies tend to rely heavily on character interactions and Fukushima Jun gave a lot of personality to Kazuma. His performance is good but doesn't compare to the level and depth of the others above him which nets him the 4th spot on this list.
nominees.staff: Jun Fukushima

nominees.writeup: While it's true that Toshiyuki Morikawa did a great job at showing the various sides of Kira, we think that his performance was of the expected for a JoJo character, and didn't bring anything new or unique to the table, not leaving any marks to remember.
nominees.staff: Toshiyuki Morikawa

nominees.writeup:
Kazuma Satou, professional NEET, dies a rather inglorious death and is given two possibilities by the rather obnoxious goddess Aqua: continue on to Heaven or reincarnate into another world.

Deciding to not pass upon the dream of every gamer, Kazuma decides to start a new life in a fantasy world but not before forcing the annoying goddess to accompany him.
nominees.staff: Rie Takahashi

nominees.writeup: Matsuoka Yoshitsugu's performance as this crazed devotee will probably leave a lasting mark in the history of VA performances. The mild calmness you can hear in his voice adds layers to Betelgeuse's madness. He really steals the show as soon as he appeared and the way Matsuoka portrays his insanity helps so much in making it believable that stuff being done to Subaru is truly twisted. The two other performances were on a whole other level but there was a method to his madness and that earns Matsuoka's performance as Betelgeuse the third spot on this list.
nominees.staff: Yoshitsugu Matsuoka

nominees.writeup: Tomoyo Kurosawa's performance as Kumiko Oumae is one of the most realistic high school girl performances ever. Though the variety of noises Tomoyo makes are fantastic, what truly sets her acting apart is her intonation.  The change in tone Kumiko has between the lower, apathetic voice she uses when with her family versus the high pitched voice she uses among Hazuki and Midori is subtle but noticeable.  Such clever intonation adds a layer of depth to her character that would otherwise not exist had she talked with her family exactly like she talked with her friends.  Tomoyo Kurosawa would have been a surefire win for best voice actress had it not been for how unbelievably fantastic Ishida Akira's performance in Rakugo was.
nominees.staff: Tomoyo Kurosawa

nominees.writeup: The passion and precision of Ishida Akira's portrayal of Rakugo's protagonist played a huge role in the show's success. We first see him as the dignified Master of his craft, with his detached demeanor and biting tongue, before he slips into otherworldly character as a shinigami and captivates both the local audience and the viewer alike. The story follows Yakumo's life in rakugo from a young starving actor, into a rising talent, and eventually through the ranks to the reluctant role of Master. Ishida perfectly captures the fledgling Bon, the seductive Kikuhiko, and the absolute mastery of Yakumo… all while providing the audience with glimpses into the threads that bind these and other variations of the same character.
nominees.staff: Akira Ishida

nominees.writeup: "Welcome to Pure Illusion"  and welcome to a fantastic soundtrack. Using a set of instruments as varied as its own show's themes, Flip Flappers has an OST that can only be described as eccentric. From toy pianos to Korean throat singing to Australian didgeridoos, no timbre is out of reach. Unfortunately, it can be a little hard to pick apart the show's soundtrack due in part to how eclectic it aims to be. With a show so full of symbolism, we felt they could have done more with motif work to really bring out something extra in the characters.
nominees.staff: Composed by TO-MAS

nominees.writeup:
Mob Psycho 100 had an OST that was very fitting for the show, there's this creepy tune to it that remains through the whole soundtrack and gives some consistency to it while also exploring the creepy nature of the supernatural such as ESP powers.

The tracks as songs however are largely forgettable with only one standout song really, It also feels like there's a lot of things Mob could do with its soundtrack that it didn't and frankly some of the synth effects that are used in the soundtrack just kill any excitement for the OST, with all this said however, the OSTs were very good this year and coupled with the show the same goes for MP100 which is why it made it onto the list as number 6.
nominees.staff: Composed by Kenji Kawai

nominees.altname: JoJo Part IV: Diamond is Unbreakable
nominees.writeup:
JoJo manages to create a vibrant soundtrack with a variety of types in it that manages to inspire life in Morioh city and captures the feeling of "coolness" that Diamond is Unbreakable strives after with its character, the soundtrack is very 90s influenced and has a lot of hints towards earlier seasons in the tracks with inspires a sense of familiarity towards JoJo.

There's a lot of building done towards the characters with the soundtrack and they emphasize specific parts of each character very well with the character themed tracks and the album as a whole is fantastic with so strong standout tracks, that's why JoJo takes 2nd for us.
nominees.staff: Composed by Yuugo Kanno

nominees.writeup:
What would the world be like if 80 percent of the population manifested extraordinary superpowers called "Quirks" at age four? Heroes and villains would be battling it out everywhere! Becoming a hero would mean learning to use your power, but where would you go to study? U.A. High's Hero Program of course! But what would you do if you were one of the 20 percent who were born Quirkless?

Middle school student Izuku Midoriya wants to be a hero more than anything, but he hasn't got an ounce of power in him. With no chance of ever getting into the prestigious U.A. High School for budding heroes, his life is looking more and more like a dead end. Then an encounter with All Might, the greatest hero of them all gives him a chance to change his destiny…
nominees.staff: Composed by Yuki Hayashi

nominees.writeup: Like most Slice of Life anime, Hibike had one significant problem expressed across the board; nothing really stands out. There are gorgeous songs that didn't actually appear in full while the show was running and great performance pieces but once you look at the rest of the show, it all starts to fall a little flat. They're great songs to have just going in the background and the whole soundtrack is gorgeous, but they're a little uninteresting. While it's more of a cinematography mark, a couple of our judges were impressed by the accuracy with which the instruments are animated. This feature, however, was not enough to push our opinion of it as a sound track any higher.
nominees.staff: Composed by Akito Matsuda

nominees.writeup:
Yuri!!! on Ice had a lot of split opinions, some liked it while others didn't but the general consensus at least is that the OST played during the skating scenes is fantastic while the rest of the show is kinda iffy.

There's a lot of standout tracks here such as Yuri on Ice, On Love: Eros, Partizan Hope or Theme of King J.J and they're all rightfully hyped up as they're fantastic tracks in their own right that captures the personality of the corresponding character or parts of their personal struggles and aims very well but it's just not enough to make it to the top with the lackluster OST outside of the skating, still, Yuri on Ice!!!! was really good in this department and that's why it takes 5th.
nominees.staff: Composed by Taku Matsushiba, Taro Umebayashi

nominees.writeup:
Re:Zero's soundtrack is one that excels at capturing the tragedy tone. The lighter moments of the show is able to create a soft, relaxing and joyful mood to easily luring the viewer into a false sense of security.

The soundtrack becomes truly phenomenal with its usage of electronic, orchestra, strings and haunting vocals especially to create a creepy atmosphere and raise the dramatic tension. The string instruments are used to great effect to encapsulate Subaru's desire of not wanting to die, his psychological trauma of losing everything over and over again in his mind and his struggles against his inescapable fate. "Requiem of Silence", which was used in the 15th episode was able to communicate the feelings witnessing an horrendous event followed by the dread of lingering hopelessness. The album is filled with similar standout tracks, which is why we consider it to be the  best OST of 2016.
nominees.staff: Composed by Kenichiro Suehiro

sections.name: Main
sections.blurb: The anime of the year. The greatest of them all. These awards divide each anime from 2018 by format, and the very best among each one was awarded the title of best short, best movie, best original and the coveted best anime of the year.

nominees.writeup: A boy wants to be a master DJ whilst mastering tonkatsu? Apparently there are a lot more similarities than one would think. The story and characters are simple and one-dimensional but the execution is well done with a unique premise that makes it quite the memorable watch for a short. However it's ultimately a very hit or miss show with its comedy and characters.
nominees.staff:
Studio DEEN

Directed by Akitarou Daichi

nominees.writeup: An adult comedy with a more unique and therefore not as accessible style. The character study of the show represents some human struggles of parenting and that serious theme stays consistent throughout despite the amount of gags. Not for everyone but in the end the amount of dirty humor with flawed personalities enforce the plot twist, that while being a bit disappointing still gets across an emotional message.
nominees.staff:
Haoliners Animation League

Directed by Haoling Li, Shinichi Watanabe

nominees.writeup:
The anime follows the everyday lives of three high school girls who are close friends: Galko, Otako, and Ojou. Galko is a slightly foul-mouthed but good-natured girl who is popular in her class. Her hobby is film appreciation. Otako is a girl who sits in the corner of the classroom, but for some reason is good friends with Galko. Ojou is an airheaded girl who often talks with Galko and Otako.

Each of the girls' names refers to their type. Galko is a pun on gyaru or gal, which is a term used to describe a type of street fashion where women in their teens and 20s bleach their hair and wear highly decorated nails and a lot of makeup. Otako is a pun on otaku, and Ojou refers to a girl who is a daughter of a high-class family.
nominees.staff:
feel.


Keiichirou Kawaguchi

nominees.altname: She and Her Cat: Everything Flows
nominees.writeup: She and her cat felt like it took full advantage of audience's emotions and use them for a stronger impact in an extremely simple story. This is visible from the usage of narration through the cat's mind to the painting-like visuals. However the story leans so heavily on its concept that it doesn't bother delivering that much on the story aspect. The events still conclude the same way they would in a typical show despite the cat's involvement but the idea still deserves recognition for being something different and emotional but still simple and short.
nominees.staff:
LIDENFILMS

Directed by Kazuya Sakamoto

nominees.writeup:
Long story short, other than the visuals and the hit or miss music, everything else fell apart. Simple, heartwarming story that felt rather shallow and the pacing over 6 minutes felt rushed, for good reasons. The connection made between Shelter and the judges was lacklustre. At the end of the day, Shelter is your everyday puppet- it looks good from the outside but is hollow on the inside. 

Shelter is a good watch but at the same time, a good waste of 6 minutes.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures


Directed by Toshifumi Akai

nominees.writeup:
The winner of the best short award without discussion between the judges, Saiki Kusuo no psi-nan was a hilarious comedy based around Saiki, a teenager born with psychic powers in a normal world, that just wants to live a quiet life.

This anime had a really fun and lovable cast of characters, and the comedy was consistently hilarious from start to end, with a lot of variety due to the characters different psychic powers he has, there were also quite a lot of great parodies, that were from series and people popular enough to be funny to everyone, and some fantastic fourth wall breaks.
nominees.staff:
J.C. Staff

Directed by Hiroaki Sakurai

nominees.writeup:
Coming in hot at the number 2 spot we have Space Patrol Luluco! Space Patrol Luluco is a Trigger special targeted at all the studio Trigger fans out there. However, with well execution all around the board, it is a short series that can be picked up by all to enjoy (with the exception that you are an individual which hates on the works by Trigger) 

At the end of the day, with a simple plotline, over the top humour and a strong showing in visuals and audio, Space Patrol Luluco is a short series that deserves the attention of all avid anime fans. It is fun, it is short and most likely, it takes just that little bit of time out of your day to reward you with something special. Space Patrol Luluco is an all in one package. The over the top references from prior works of Trigger serving as fanservice and also its unique and original idea just becomes the cherry on top of something that is already great. This is a short series that possesses the ability to make its very own 7 minute episodes feel as long as a full fledged episode.
nominees.staff:
Trigger


Directed by Hiroyuki Imaishi

nominees.writeup: One Piece: Gold is an excellent installation in the One Piece franchise. Although it's a lot to compact into a short 2 hours, everything you expect from the crew is on display once again. There was strong "ship" building and making the entire area a pleasantly good time, despite the occasional awkward CGI. The supporting cast is as you would expect for your average One Piece story with a new addition for Nami's backstory that gives them a deeper connection. That being said, there were definitely faults. For those who aren't familiar with the series, it's a bit tougher to follow and enjoy as much, but still a good showing. The main villain in the movie is brought about as the villain quite well, but a shoe-horned backstory that is supposed to make you sympathize with him, feels completely disjointed as the villain never reflects on it or makes any notice to change based on past experiences. Overall a solid movie amongst the list of other nominees.
nominees.staff:
Toei Animation

Directed by Hiroaki Miyamoto

nominees.writeup:
Classmates is a short movie that tackles a culturally difficult subject, gay love. Unlike other shows that pussyfoot around the topic as a whole, here we get a realistic romance story with believable characters. The relationship was heartwarming and every kiss felt like they were a normal couple.

However, everything that wasn't about the relationship suffered. Some plot developments didn't feel fully setup and/or not elaborated on, the teacher perving was unnecessary, it focuses too much on the romantic relationship that it fails to provide context or characterisation outside of it and suffers from the classic anime syndrome of miscommunication. While it deals with some mature themes very well, it doesn't really have anything to offer outside of the relationship and is largely monotonous.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures

Directed by Shouko Nakamura

nominees.writeup:
Anthem of the Heart tells a fairly mundane tale of drama in a mundane high school setting. Most of its animation is also fairly mundane - competent but nothing particularly exemplary. But there is nothing mundane about Anthem's engrossing writing which grips your heart within moments of the film's beginning and holds it through a satisfying build-up of themes and emotion all the way until the climactic finale. Nor is there anything mundane about the directing, which makes expert use of differing art styles to highlight the fantastical conceits of the narrative in a way that only anime can.

Additionally, Anthem presents a masterclass in character animation. The "character acting" of Naruse in particular is a revelation, showcasing a plethora of complex and intertwined emotions.

Add to all of that some great sound design, characters that will defy your expectations, and a heart-pounding finale - Anthem of the Heart was by far our standout winner for best film of the year.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures

Directed by Tatsuyuki Nagai

nominees.writeup: Manages to prove once again how many different kinds of movies Mamoru can direct while still keeping an identifiable style. The visuals especially fight choreography are appealing even in some of the CG heavy scenes and the action overall is solid. There's an emotional journey to adulthood present throughout the movie that get shown in various unique ways and with the aid of multiple characters. The villain lacks proper intro as do some slight plot elements but it's still an entertaining film with a beautiful message.
nominees.staff:
Studio Chizu

Directed by Mamoru Hosoda

nominees.writeup: Girls und Panzer der Film shines most when it's having fun showing cute girls doing tank things. Unfortunately, it decides to spend a drawn out middle portion of the film attempting to set up drama that feels hackneyed. The visuals don't exactly look bad but nothing looks amazing either. Along with plot armor thicker than the plating on a Maus and some song choices that make more sense when you've watched the show, this movie suffers in comparison to the rest of the competition. It should be noted, however, that if you're in the mood for watching some tanks doing tank things, it is a ton of fun.
nominees.staff:
Actas

Directed by Tsutomu Mizushima

nominees.writeup: Kizumonogatari is the long awaited prequel of the Monogatari franchise and yet it winds up low on this list. Why?  Well, it suffered heavily from not taking the time to properly introduce its characters and instead leaned upon the series to frame them for you. Had each movie had a full two hour experience with it, perhaps we could have gotten a little more. Compared against everything released before it, the lack of Araragi's inner monologue makes it feel hollow in comparison. The story is still great for any fan of the series but across the jury, we each felt something detracted from the tone and quality of the whole presentation.
nominees.staff:
Shaft

Directed by Tatsuya Oishi, Akiyuki Shinbo

nominees.writeup: Bones did an absolutely magnificent job this year. The production of the second seasons of both Shirayuki-hime and ConRevo were both hugely loved by their respective audience, managing to follow or even surpass their first seasons. Boku no Hero Academia was hailed to be a brilliant adaptation, earning much praise. And of course the show that solidifies Bones as the definite winner of the Studio of the Year Award, Mob Psycho 100 was one of the most brilliant works done by them to date. One small mark on Bones was the first season of Bungou Stray Dogs, but that mark is indeed small, and the second season certainly made up for it. Overall, a fantastic lineup of shows resulting in a completely unanimous win.

Studio Deen has a fairly polarizing few from some judges, but overall their highs were too great and their lows weren’t bad enough to take away from a fittingly strong year for Deen. Konosuba and Rakugo Shinjuu in particular stood out as strong Anime of the Year candidates that excelled in what both shows sought out to accomplish. While other studios on this list may have had 1 really amazing stand out show, Deen managed to put out 2 within the same season. While Sakamoto and Tonkatsu DJ were both good, Super Lovers was definitely a small but polarizing mark on their otherwise strong year. Deen’s great lineup of productions earns them a narrowly taken spot for the runner up of the year.

A-1 pictures had one of the best years it has had in a long time, producing no less than four quality shows and a very well made and popular music video. Erased was one of the most popular shows during its runtime and, even if the ending was seen as lackluster by a lot, was one of the biggest shows of the year. Aside from that, Hai to Gensou no Grimgar and Occultic;Nine were two other shows they produced, and while Grimgar certainly had production issues throughout its run, these are still two solid productions in the end. They also adapted the WWW.Working!!, and of course the highly popular and valued Shelter. Ace Attorney is unfortunately a black mark on their score, but all in all a very good lineup of shows from them this year.

This year could be considered Trigger’s best year since 2014 when Kill la Kill aired. They produced two shows this year, both in the same season. Kiznaiver ended up a popular and generally well received show and was adored by many, but was also thought to lack the usual Trigger style that many of their shows are absolutely drenched in. 

Contrarily, what could be considered the most Trigger-esque show to date is Space Patrol Luluco. For fans of Trigger, this show was an absolute blast, functioning much like a love letter to their own shows in the best way imaginable.

For a small studio like Trigger, it is very impressive of them to create two great and especially original shows, a feat earning them a good place on the list. Still, despite being a small studio, an output of only a show and a short results in Trigger being unable to land any higher.

Between an excellent adaptation of the second season of Shokugeki, one of, if not the funniest comedies of the year in Saiki K, and solid slice-of-life stories in Amanchu and Flying Witch, J. C. Staff has shown meticulous handling in their adaptations. In fact, if it weren’t for one horrendous black mark, J.C. Staff would be several spots higher. Mistakes are perfectly forgivable, but Taboo Tattoo really pushes the envelope on that. Ultimately, 4 very solid shows allowed J.C. Staff to barely edge out David Productions in the rankings, but we still don’t like Taboo Tattoo.

This year, David Production made what is considered by many to be the best JoJo part yet, Diamond is Unbreakable. With an 39 episode long airtime, it took up most of the year and put DP as a contender for one of the best studios this year. A less known show they produced was Planetarian, a small but well liked show that earned DP that extra push into the nominations list.

Shaft led a low-key year, only releasing Kizumonogatari Parts 1 and 2, and Koyomimonogatari in full. However, the Kizumonogatari films are among the most confidently produced, passionately crafted, and ultimately highest quality anime films out there, exceeding the expectations that years worth of hype and delays had built. Koyomimonogatari was a much more low-key production, serving only to act as a love letter to the Monogatari fans and to set up the stakes for Owari season 2, and noticeably lacking much of the luxuries typically afforded to a season of Monogatari.

In the end, their low rate of output and some shortcomings with the production of Koyomimonogatari hold Shaft back, but the skill and style that embodies Kizumonogatari still manages to put them a nudge ahead other studios.

TMS earned a nomination spot for having stand out shows in ReLife and Sweetness and Lightning. Although Orange, despite being solid for the first half, fell up a bit short toward the end and Bakuon was underwhelming, they were still overall solid shows that as a combined package led TMS to stand out in the Slice & Life genre.

In comparison to the others nominated, TMS fell up short, particularly from a production standpoint being ever so narrowly beat out in quality. So close, but no Bananya.

White Fox Co., Ltd. (Japanese: 株式会社 WHITE FOX, Hepburn: Kabushiki gaisha Howaito Fokkusu), is a Japanese animation studio. The studio's most successful productions include adaptations of Steins;Gate, Akame ga Kill! and Re:Zero − Starting Life in Another World.

Tanaka-kun is Always Listless is a chill comedy, which is equal parts hilarious and comfy. The show has incredible confidence in its premise with its smart direction, soothing artstyle, calming soundtrack, inducing a sense of comfort Tanaka himself would envy, but its impeccable comic timing, and one of the best ensembles this year, never fails to elicit laughter. All of which makes Tanaka-kun a weird concoction that just works, and a worthy pick as the eighth best anime of the year.

nominees.writeup: Yuri on Ice is the classic tale of an underdog affirming his resolve and rising to glory in a rarely talked about sport. It is above all, a love letter to figure skating, that celebrates its multicultural nature through a wide and varied assortment of interesting characters. Its positive portrayal of a queer relationship was refreshing to see, and was integral to its breakout success. Despite suffering from production issues and a rather messy story structure, Yuri on Ice succeeded in expressing its themes and emotional narrative uniquely, a success that has won the series the ninth slot on this list.

Desperate to save the victim, he sends himself back in time only to find himself as a grade-schooler one month before fellow classmate Kayo Hinazuki went missing. Satoru now embarks on a new quest: to save Kayo and solve the mystery behind her disappearance.

nominees.writeup: Flip Flappers is a series of episodic adventures with vibrant animation and dynamic fight sequences, that could be wondrous, horrific, tense, or exciting depending on the episode's theme.  Layered with symbols and references, and hiding a deeper narrative about a young girls struggle for identity and self, Flip Flappers' twisted bildungsroman was a veritable adventure onto itself. As any work of art, the show's depth depends on your own input and interpretation of its text, subtext and metatext, and writing about them could fill entire essays, but even as a piece of entertainment it's enthralling adventures make it a deserving candidate for the third best show of the year.

nominees.writeup: The enigmatic JoJo's Bizarre Adventure returns to the medium in a resounding form, being every bit as fabulous, creative, macho, impossible and kickass as its predecessors, escalating the potent bravado exuded by the show to unfathomable proportions. Its blatant disregard for the most elementary rules of writing is its greatest strength, and its eccentricity its greatest appeal, neglecting plausibility in service of uncompromising and exhilarating climaxes, even if its two strengths may not appeal to everyone, it easily earned itself fifth place.

nominees.writeup: KonoSuba is a refreshing take on the Isekai subgenre, with its parodic, almost mean spirited humor, and interesting cast of characters particularly Kazuma, Aqua and Megumin. The show's penchant for overusing certain gags, and a slightly weak side cast, were the only real negatives. Aside from that it features some fantastic VA performances, an ingenious soundtrack, top notch comic timing, and Deen's unique and charming animation. It's a hilarious romp of a drunk DnD session, that deserves its place as one of the best shows of the year.

nominees.writeup: Mob Psycho 100 is a creative smorgasbord of breathtaking animation, packaging a standard shounen story of a young boy's desire to improve himself. However, it has a unique twist up its sleeve, in Mob, a protagonist who doesn't value his psychic powers, something most others would give anything for, but who instead wants to become a better member of society and just be normal, add in a stellar supporting cast in particular Reigen, Ritsu and Teru, with unique arcs of their own, healthy dosage of comedy, some of the best fights in existence and an ending that is poetic and heartwarming, and Mob Psycho becomes an irresistible package that deserves all its plaudits, and the fourth place on our list.

nominees.writeup: Shouwa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu is the kind of story we all too rarely see in anime. A period drama about two young actors set throughout the initial decline and then postwar resurgence of their craft, the best word for Rakugo's charm is intoxication. The show immerses you in its world; whether by the sensuous jazz and tattoo of drums accompanying the theatre performances, the layered performances of the voice actors who quite literally breathe life into the script, or simply the streets and nightlife of the 1950s swirling around you, Rakugo draws you further and further downward toward a predestined (yet still satisfying) conclusion. If the rest of this list showcases excellent animation, action, and exuberance, Rakugo is unique in its more subdued yet equally passionate artistic vision. Fans of more traditional fare might balk at the concept, however the jury was nearly unanimous in their acclaim… Shouwa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu is modern masterpiece.

nominees.writeup: Oh, Re:Zero. Certainly, it was the most talked about show of the year, as it took an unexpectedly dark spin on the currently trending isekai premise. What sells this anime as one of the best series of the year is its harshly critical take on the "otaku hero" protagonist, hitting so close to home it hurts. That makes it a show you can't simply walk past by, even if you take issue with some of its flaws. Admittedly it's one of those Light Novel adaptations that never manage to give justice to the true potential of its fantasy world and enough screentime to the broad ensemble cast it presents, but what we saw was enough to keep the audience on the edge of its seat, and even without any hope of continuation, it's striking emotional core, whose dramatic impact struck a chord with many in the jury, earns it a well-deserved seventh place on the list.
